awd_titl_txt: Function of Early Incubation:  Tests of Social and          Environmental Constraints
awd_abstract_narration: 9407349  Beissinger                              Abstract                                  Offspring represent parental investment in the future.  In  evolutionary terms, this means that parents should generally  behave in ways that maximize the number of offspring they  raise.  Certain aspects of this fundamental biological  question can be particularly well-studied in birds because  birds control the development of their young by when and how  they incubate eggs.  Dr. Beissinger will test several  hypotheses about the adaptive  nature of parental behavior through a series of field  experiments which will examine different adaptive functions  of incubation behavior.  The results will be integrated into  a hierarchical model of reproduction and will help to  develop our understanding of the biology of reproduction.  In addition, because many close relatives of the species Dr.  Beissinger works with are endangered, this research will  have implications for conservation biology.
